The complex and often fragile relationship between the able and disabled is displayed in Martyna Majok’s Pulitzer Prize Winning drama The Cost of Living, offering the audience insight into the human struggle to need and be needed.

Working elliptically and with remarkable economy of means, the playwright creates a portrait in miniature of a society that, all too often, leaves the poor, disabled, and psychologically lost to fend for themselves. At the same time, her dialogue crackles with wit and understated feeling.

The History Boys is a play that celebrates the joy of learning and the complex relationships between teachers and students, brought to Broadway with intelligence and wit intact.
The production crackles with intelligence and humor.
Alan Bennett's witty, wise and deeply affecting play arrives on Broadway with its superb original cast intact.
Mr. Guare's play is a masterpiece of American comedy, and this production does it justice.
John Guare's 1971 comedy 'The House of Blue Leaves' receives a crackling revival that finds the perfect pitch between pathos and hilarity.
Karam's play is a masterpiece of ordinary dread, finding horror in the everyday anxieties of a middle-class family gathering for Thanksgiving dinner.
That alone should keep this lovely play, an Off Broadway transfer, running in its inviting new Broadway house until kingdom come.
While the larger vision and the major performance lack distinction, the pleasures of this revival are derived from seeing the ensemble bring O'Neill's characters to life.
Wolfe and Washington and a marvelous cast demonstrate that the play is indeed a monumental piece of theater.
This is a performance of hypnotic authority.
Under George C. Wolfe's direction, O'Neill's epic feels less like an endurance test than a gripping investigation of American disillusionment.

If some of The Inheritance is surprisingly glib, it nevertheless remains a mostly well-written and observant work that successfully studies contrasts in generational attitudes-and socio-political awareness-even as it features several deeply poignant sequences.

Theatergoers fortunate enough to have seen the original cast in the original productions of such two-part dramas as Nicholas Nickleby and Angels in America will likely tell you that those experiences remain unforgettable. The Inheritance hereby joins that list. Pure theatrical magnificence.
This sumptuous revival is a visual feast that mostly delivers on its promise.
This revival is sumptuous and satisfying, with Kelli O'Hara and Ken Watanabe bringing fresh magic to the classic musical.
This revival is a gorgeous, sumptuous production that honors the original while making it feel fresh and relevant for today's audiences.
This production succeeds because it takes Rodgers and Hammerstein's show seriously, treating it as the complex, nuanced work it actually is.
This revival is a handsome, well-sung production that honors the show's considerable virtues while mostly sidestepping its obvious problems.
This lavish revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein's 1951 musical is a feast for the eyes and ears, with Kelli O'Hara delivering a luminous performance as Anna.
Kelli O'Hara and Ken Watanabe bring fresh depth and nuance to the classic Rodgers and Hammerstein musical
Chalk up another triumph for Theater.
It’s certainly among the best concluding utterances in literary annals. Sincere condolences to the spectator who isn’t greatly moved by it.
Spangler's absorbing adaptation... moves things along rather well on a smartly sparse set.
This faithful adaptation brings emotional weight to the stage, though it occasionally feels constrained by its reverence for the source material.

This stage adaptation of Khaled Hosseini's bestselling novel about friendship, betrayal and redemption in Afghanistan is beautifully designed and sensitively performed, but it struggles to capture the epic sweep of its source material.
The Kite Runner is more of a vivid recitation than fully realized drama.

The Last Ship is an earnest, well-intentioned musical that never quite finds its sea legs.
Sting's musical about shipbuilders in his native England has strong moments but feels more like a work in progress than a polished Broadway show.

Sting has written a deeply personal musical about the death of the shipbuilding industry in his native England, but for all its sincerity and craft, 'The Last Ship' never quite finds its sea legs on Broadway.

The Last Ship is a gorgeous failure — gorgeous because Sting's songs are often beautiful and because the cast performs them with stirring commitment, but a failure because the story never finds its sea legs.
The Lehman Trilogy proves an unalloyed theatrical triumph.

Theatrical astonishment is back on the Broadway boards. The Lehman Trilogy, which has conquered and enraptured audiences since it first appeared, has finally arrived at the Nederlander after a pandemic pause.
The Lehman Trilogy is a monumental work of theater that transforms the rise and fall of a financial dynasty into gripping, intimate drama.
It's sheer joy to have the show back in all its stately, tragic glory.
There's a feeling at the end of this atmospheric show, gorgeous and intoxicating as it often is, of a mighty steel beam bending out of true.
McDonagh has written a play that's simultaneously hilarious and horrifying, and director Wilson Milam has staged it with just the right balance of comedy and carnage.
The play The Lifespan of a Fact is an amusing evening at the theater.
As a play, Lifespan isn't much more substantial than the paper your Playbill is printed on.
The play succeeds in dramatizing the ethical complexities of fact-checking and the tension between truth and narrative.
This is terrifically funny dialogue, and both actors savor every comeback.

So now we know: The Greek gods were not helicopter parents. That's the takeaway, at least, from The Lightning Thief: The Percy Jackson Musical, adapted from the popular young readers' book by Rick Riordan, the first installment in a series that's emerged as a sort of Harry Potter lite.

Although the musical is mostly a yawn for adults (and probably smarter kids), sub-par visuals make it even a less attractive event. The production looks so cheap visually that let's be kind and not name the designers.

The Lightning Thief: The Percy Jackson Musical is a show that knows its audience and serves it well, delivering a colorful, energetic adaptation that captures the spirit of Rick Riordan's beloved books.

"Make no mistake: The Lion King is a rare theater experience. The musical is intelligent spectacle, extravagance with a purpose -- and a heart. From the moment it begins, The Lion King offers astonishing stage magic.
The Lion King is a visual masterpiece that transports audiences to the African savanna...
A triumph of theatrical imagination that reinvents the Disney animated classic for the stage...
Director Julie Taymor has fashioned a visual feast that is both dazzling and surprisingly intimate...
The Lion King can make you fall in love with theater no matter what theater it's in.

"'The Lion King' was astonishing, in the jaw-dropping manner of speaking. And today, 21 years later, it still is...Taymor, the avant-garde director to whom Disney entrusted the piece, outdid herself...Everything still looks wonderful, and looks practically brand new, too.
A stunning stage event. Combining a graceful horde of actors, singers and dancers with a stylized world of fantastic puppets and theatrical wonderment.
A breathtaking spectacle that captures the spirit of Africa with stunning puppetry and costumes...
The most visually stunning Broadway musical in years...
A theatrical experience unlike any other, thanks to director Julie Taymor...
An exciting piece of theater for everyone but especially for those unfamiliar with Disney's brilliant, Oscar-winning 1994 animated film...
The Lion King is a show that succeeds on almost every level, creating a theatrical experience that is both breathtaking and moving.
There is simply nothing else like it. Julie Taymor has taken the sweet but somewhat insubstantial story of the Disney movie and transformed it into a meditation on the great cycle of life.

Julie Taymor has created a visual spectacular that is unlike anything else on Broadway, transforming the Theater into an African savanna where actors become antelopes, birds, and lions through ingenious costumes and masks.
Taymor populates the stage with an amazing menagerie of beasts; her audacious staging expands a simple cub into the pride of Broadway, not merely a fable of heredity but a celebration of heritage.

While Disney's stage adaptation of 'The Little Mermaid' delivers the expected visual splendor and memorable songs, the show feels more like an expensive theme park attraction than compelling musical theater.

Nicky Silver's dysfunctional family comedy 'The Lyons' is a nasty piece of work that gets nastier as it goes along, which is not necessarily a bad thing when the material is this sharply written and the performances are this good.

Al Pacino's Shylock is a compelling figure, but the production around him is uneven and at times confusing in its interpretive choices.
Tracy Letts' searing drama 'The Minutes' is a masterful exploration of how communities construct and maintain their mythologies.

Audience mileage will vary on the play which transforms itself from a satirical comedy about small-town bureaucracy to a dark vision of historical revisionism and collective guilt. Lett’s audacious conceit doesn’t fully work in its lengthy build-up and abrupt transition to surrealism.
The Minutes spins entirely out of control.
The play's final revelation is genuinely shocking, and Mr. Letts delivers it with the skill of a master dramatist.
It shows us how we are starting to understand, but still mostly failing to accept, that our privileges are tied to a history of denying them to others.
The Minutes is a play that builds to a revelation that recontextualizes everything that has come before, and when that revelation arrives, it lands with genuine force.
It is thrilling and essential theater that interrogates the present by laying bare how history is written.
Mr. Guirgis has created a work that pulses with the rhythm of real life and real pain, even when it occasionally stumbles over its own good intentions.

Nathan Lane gives a performance of such depth and humanity that it transforms what could have been a standard backstage weepie into something genuinely moving.

The Nap, which opens tonight in a Manhattan Theatre Club production at the Samuel J. Friedman, is the staged version of those not-quite-right British sitcoms. It is funny, but less funny than you'd like it to be. It entertains, but it is instantly forgotten. You can't shake the feeling that you're missing something.

Delicious new comedy directed with an assured balance of blatancy and subtlety by Daniel Sullivan.

This piece would be a pleasant few minutes on the radio. Apparently it was well-received off-Broadway at the Cherry Lane over the summer. Designer Beowulf Boritt has created an elegantly simple set (and provides the single theatrical moment that I'm not supposed to talk about).

This week on Broadway, each and every reference to "the new one" no doubt referred to a gargantuan animatronic ape. Now we can wipe that out with Birbiglia's The New One. Not as big and spectacular as King Kong, needless to say, but gargantuanuously more entertaining.

Larry Kramer's furious 1985 drama about the early years of the AIDS crisis burns with undiminished urgency in this superb Broadway revival, directed with searing intensity by Joel Grey and George C. Wolfe.

This middle play of Ayckbourn's trilogy works best as a standalone piece, with its clever staging of romantic chaos in real time. The cast handles the intricate comic timing with skill.

The bombastic musical that opened Thursday at the Theatre is about a love for the ages but has understated songs by Ingrid Michaelson, who offers coffee house vibes instead of passion’s thunder. The book by Bekah Brunstetter loses gas well before it’s over and piles on the melodrama.

a trip down memory lane on stage and off

The musical adaptation of Nicholas Sparks' beloved novel and subsequent film manages to capture the sweeping romance and emotional intensity that made the story so enduring, while adding layers of musical theater magic that elevate the source material.

Because writing for character means writing in distinct voices, there’s a thin line in musical theater songwriting between the simple and the simplistic: Unlike her gratifyingly accessible pop music, Michaelson’s score here falls on the wrong side too much of the time.

Dementia is a horrifically flattening illness. But it is difficult to sustain the show’s over two hour runtime on the question of reconciliation. The musical adaptation of Nicholas Sparks' romance novel is a handsomely mounted production that hits all the expected emotional beats, even if it doesn't always transcend its source material's more saccharine qualities.
Love is powerful. Dementia is sad. The result can be heartbreaking.

Instead, Brunstetter’s book, which spreads thin as it flits back and forth through a half-century, resists delineating the central pair with much of any identifying detail. The Notebook is a show that knows exactly what it is and delivers it with unflinching commitment, even when that commitment leads to emotional manipulation of the highest order.
All of it presents a beautiful picture of mortality, but also the universality of love.

The Notebook is a musical that knows exactly what it is: a big, swoony, unabashedly romantic spectacle that trades in the currency of feelings.
Laurie Metcalf delivers a tour de force in this harrowing drama about a neurologist who may be losing her mind.
Laurie Metcalf gives a performance of stunning intensity and emotional truth as a brilliant scientist whose mind is beginning to fragment.

Metcalf delivers a performance of such emotional intensity and intellectual rigor that it seems to emerge from some deep, private place of understanding about the mysteries of consciousness and identity.

Hinton novel (and Francis Ford Coppola movie) but a genuinely great American musical. Everything about this production feels original and dynamic. Directed by Danya Taymor, it’s a terrific collaboration highlighting all of the novel’s virtues while sidestepping most of the clunkier aspects. Many in the gifted cast are making their Broadway debuts; and the entire experience is enhanced by a creative team marked by youthful energy.

The Outsiders succeeds brilliantly at making you feel like you're part of this world, with performances that crackle with authenticity and a production design that puts you right in the middle of 1960s Tulsa.

The production is the platonic ideal of a retro classic rebooted for Broadway, broadly appealing to audiences young and old (my showing was split between boomers and kids) but not particularly searing, recognizable but not terribly distinct, sincere and competent yet not resounding.

In Tulsa, Oklahoma, 1967, Ponyboy Curtis, his best friend Johnny Cade and their Greaser family of "outsiders" battle with their affluent rivals, the Socs. This thrilling new Broadway musical navigates the complexities of self-discovery as the Greasers dream about who they want to become in a world that may never accept them.

This revival has been mounted with such care and affection that it feels less like an exhumation than a homecoming.

Paul Reubens' gloriously goofy man-child returns in fine fettle, surrounded by the colorful denizens of his wonderfully warped world in a show that's both a nostalgic throwback and a welcome reminder of inspired silliness.

We’re completely rapt, and by the end, we see the piano for what it really is: the embodiment of three generations of family history, and the physical representation of their slave narrative.
The first Broadway revival of August Wilson's 'The Piano Lesson' is full of stars and ghosts. The ghosts are what make it brilliant.
The Piano Lesson at the Barrymore Theatre has been tuned to perfection.
This revival of August Wilson's family drama is a powerhouse production that honors the playwright's legacy while finding fresh emotional truths in familiar material.

This is not story theater as one might imagine. It is a wondrous merging of technical wizardry, clever stagecraft and incomparable artistry. As you enter the theater, there’s little more than a giant screen suspended on a bare stage.
From the storytelling and innovative staging to Sarah Snook's incredible performance as numerous characters, it's a show you won't want to miss.
This production only goes skin-deep.
This bloated new musical is so benumbed by its own earnestness that it makes 'Man of La Mancha' look like a laff riot.

The Pitmen Painters is a play that wears its heart on its sleeve, and though it occasionally threatens to become overly sentimental, it succeeds in telling a moving story about the transformative power of art.
This British import is a delightful disaster that works because it takes tremendous skill to look so skillless.
But for all the strenuous effort involved, the repetitive show evaporates in your mind the moment it concludes.
Under the go-for-broke direction of Mark Bell, its high-energy cast is comic gold.
Blanchett is magnificent in this adaptation of Chekhov's first play, but the production around her feels uncertain and overwrought.

Blanchett brings her fierce intelligence and commanding stage presence to bear on the role of Anna Petrovna, a wealthy widow whose romantic entanglements drive the plot of this leisurely paced but ultimately rewarding drama.

Miller's drama about two brothers confronting their past and their father's legacy remains as powerful and relevant as ever, and this revival does it justice with fine performances from Danny DeVito, Mark Ruffalo, Tony Shalhoub, and Jessica Hecht.

This production succeeds in finding the humor and humanity in what can be a heavy, schematic work.
The production succeeds in large part because of the four superb performances at its center.
Miller's drama about family, responsibility and regret gets a solid revival with Danny DeVito and Mark Ruffalo.
Terry Kinney directs a superlative cast who make this revival a treasured experience.
Surprisingly funny, finding the dark comedy that lurks beneath the family's bitter recriminations.

Indeed, it's hard to imagine a show fueled by more extravagant good will than Prom, which Nicholaw put together with old friends and collaborators Chad Beguelin, Bob Martin and Matthew Sklar, with Martin and Beguelin co-writing the book and the latter crafting lyrics for Sklar's music.
Everyone gamely and capably projects their characters, especially Leavel and Ashmanskas, who probably spit out nails after chewing so much scenery in their outsized roles as Dee Dee and Barry.

Such a joyful hoot...it makes you believe in musical comedy again.
The Prom is a big, bouncy musical that wears its heart on its sequined sleeve. It's about as subtle as a pride parade float, but it's also about as joyful.
Tom Stoppard's 1982 play about love, marriage and the nature of art gets a handsome but lifeless revival that squanders a terrific cast.

Eno brings out the humanity in Henry's witty but wounding words, and his chemistry with Reilly is palpable. The Real Thing may be about the difficulty of defining authentic love, but this production captures it beautifully.

The marvelous cast of all-stars makes every syllable worth savoring.

Mr. Jackman brings his usual high-voltage charisma to the role of a man whose obsession with fly-fishing becomes a metaphor for deeper spiritual yearnings. But Jez Butterworth's poetic drama, for all its lyrical beauty, feels more like a meditation than a fully realized theatrical experience.
Hugh Jackman gives a committed performance in Jez Butterworth's mystical drama, but the play itself feels more like a beautiful riddle than a fully satisfying theatrical experience.
Hugh Jackman brings his considerable charisma and skill to bear on a mysterious, poetic drama that doesn't always reward such efforts.
Hugh Jackman gives a commanding performance in Jez Butterworth's cryptic drama about a man obsessed with fly-fishing, but the play itself remains as elusive as the salmon he's trying to catch.
Rosemary Harris gives a performance of such fierce intelligence and emotional complexity that she transforms what could have been a talky three-character play into a riveting theatrical experience.
So my disappointment in the play is not due to some casualty of heart or humanity — the show’s got well-enough doses of both — but rather its missing sense of deeper purpose.
: "I seriously doubt many audience members will regret their attendance at 'The Roommate' You just don't see performances like the one delivered by Farrow, now 79, very often."

Directed with his usual finesse by Jack O’ Brien and beautifully designed by Bob Crowley (who has created a spacious, airy Midwest farmhouse) and lit gorgeously by Natasha Katz, the play serves mostly as a showcase for the spectacular Mia Farrow (in a long-awaited return to the stage) and her real-life bestie, Patti LuPone, each of whom do their...
The Roommate has Farrow and LuPone to lean into, and their appeal is not small.

It is a supreme moment of anticipation, and, as it happens, is the high point of the evening. Silverman's play offers little more than an oddball pairing of sensibilities, the most glaring pair of opposites since Neil Simon had Oscar and Felix take up housekeeping.

It’s near-impossible to look away from Mia Farrow’s riveting performance as a lonely Iowan in Jack O’Brien‘s staging of Jen Silverman’s quirky one-act, one-set play “The Roommate.” One fears looking down at the floor for a second and missing an implosion. Maybe “explosion” is the better word. It’s hard to know.
Margo Martindale and Patti LuPone are a perfect odd couple in this intimate two-hander that feels like watching your fascinating aunts chat over wine.

Despite the fine efforts of the performers and solid production values including music by an overqualified David Yazbek, The Roommate, running 100 minutes without an intermission, always feels predictable despite its procession of narrative surprises designed for easy laughs.

There are a couple twists—one involves a rather questionable Walmart purchase—that push The Roommate from realistic into far-fetched territory. One, unfortunately, is the ending. “The playwrights are counting on familiarity to make this fanfiction float, and their own affection for the source material is clear... ‘The Shark Is Broken’ also quips about the degeneration of the entertainment business into a factory for sequels and remakes.
Beyond its good will and nostalgic conjuring, ’The Shark Is Broken’ is too slender a tale, too gentle, to provide thrills or even, truth be told, much drama.

In the end, there’s not a lot here: No crazy shark puppets, little sense of the raging seas nor of tormented, insecure actors — not much for the eye to see and very little happening that you don’t anticipate just five or 10 minutes into the show.

Incredibly, The Shark Is Broken aspires to similar depths despite its comedic trappings. On its surface, the 95-minute play is about the frustrations, petty rivalries, and not-so-secret vices that Scheider, Dreyfuss, and Shaw may have gotten up to while waiting for cameras to roll on Jaws.

In the end, there’s not a lot here: No crazy shark puppets, little sense of the raging seas nor of tormented, insecure actors — not much for the eye to see and very little happening that you don’t anticipate just five or 10 minutes into the show.
The three-man show is funny, fascinating and surprisingly moving as it dives into the psychology of three very different men stuck together on a sinking boat.

...the comfort that ‘The Shark Is Broken' brings, and it truly is a most enjoyable 95 minutes, stems from the canny way in which it channels Jaws itself...Watching ‘The Shark Is Broken,’ then, is not unlike diving into a boatload of outtakes from a beloved classic. If you’re anything like me, you eat it up like it’s popcorn.
As is the whole 95 minutes of three men—no, three actors with a broken mechanical shark—on a boat. All laughter, with no threat of a shark attack. ’Cause the shark is broken.

All three actors give uncanny impersonations that sometimes shade into nuanced portraits….The main question, though, is why do a backstage comedy about “Jaws” almost half a century after its release? The only obvious answer is that the show needed to wait until Robert Shaw’s son Ian got to be as old as his father was when he portrayed Quint… now...

‘The Shark Is Broken’ is all talk, and a pattern emerges. Shaw and Dreyfuss clash. Scheider referees. It gets repetitive over the 95-minute run time. On the plus side, there are moments when the warring trio clicks and a sort of camaraderie shines through. Plus, the co-authors seasoned the script with laughs.
...'The Shark Is Broken' isn’t an ambitious drama, just an unusual workplace dramedy with a genealogical twist.

The Shark is Broken’s scenic design is packed with memorabilia from the original film, including a floatation barrel used to track the fictional predator, but the real memories pay homage to Robert Shaw’s complicated life as an artist struggling with addiction.

‘The Shark Is Broken’ is a character study in which your level of interest will be tied to your curiosity about the trio of film actors being depicted here, all of them flummoxed by the many delays in shooting and lacking the knowledge of foresight about what ultimately will be the massive popularity and financial success of ‘Jaws’.

“Do you really think people are going to be talking about this in fifty years?” he adds a moment later, showing his crystal ball is just as faulty as it is functioning. The final shot soon-to-be-completed, the men know giddily that freedom will soon be theirs.
The Shark Is Broken is a clever, affectionate tribute to a classic film and the messy, human process of making art under pressure.

...details do not on their own create much dramatic interest. Plots consisting of hurry-up-and-wait rarely do. Were it not for its curious meta-story, the play would be little more than a pleasant diversion: 95 minutes of bloodless, toothless, Hollywood-adjacent dramedy.

‘The Shark Is Broken’ is not a play for the ages, or even for those who have never seen ‘Jaws,’ but it’s a frisky and continuously amusing diversion—perfect late-summer entertainment if you want to stay away from the ocean.
